0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-research-factbox-idUSKBN12H2JL	Factbox: Wall Street's take on possible impact of U.S. elections	"

U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Donald Trump are in a tight race ahead of the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election. Following is a weekly roundup of financial market analysts' views on the U.S. elections and the likely implications of a Trump or Clinton win on financial markets.  MORE COVERAGE: bit.ly/2dOgcoESEE RELATED FACTBOX: reut.rs/2d9cl4qDAVID KOSTIN
column2: U.S. PORTFOLIO STRATEGY RESEARCH
column3: GOLDMAN SACHS

column1: A so-called 'wave election' would occur if one party registers large congressional seat gains and has the potential to implement policy changes... Following six prior 'wave elections
column2: ' S&P 500 typically fell during the subsequent 1 and 3 months. Our strategies: buy health care equipment and services/sell pharma and biotech; own firms with high government sales; (and) own high overseas cash.""CHRIS SENYEK
column3: CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST
column4: WOLFE RESEARCH

column1: Whether it's Hillary or Trump
column2: the U.S. is unlikely to break out of secular stagnation. With respect to the election
column3: our focus will remain on the impact that the next U.S. president will likely have on fiscal and monetary policies
column4: as well as the global growth outlook. Unfortunately
column5: we don't see either candidate as likely to purse a true 'pro-growth' agenda that will break the U.S. economy out of its current malaise.""  Interest rates: ""We see rising upside risk for longer-term U.S. rates
column6: regardless of the outcome in November. The biggest upside risk for a sustained increase in longer-term rates is rising risk premiums.""Credit growth: ""With Trump's negative comments regarding Dodd-Frank
column7: our sense is a Trump victory could jumpstart lending. We believe a Hillary win would create even stiffer headwinds and more regulation for the financial services industry.""Sector recommendations:

column1: - Buy on Clinton win
column2: sell on Trump win: alternative energy
column3: housing and REITs
column4: hospitals and managed care
column5: exporters and companies with international exposure - Buy on Trump win
column6: sell on Clinton win: exploration and production
column9: high tax rate companies- Potential upside in either scenario: infrastructure companies

column1: Infrastructure spending: ""In a rare example of bipartisan support
column2: both candidates have discussed the need to repair crumbling infrastructure... The correlation between infrastructure spending and equity returns has deteriorated in recent years
column3: but candidates' outsized plans could still be a tailwind for infrastructure-levered stocks."" Names ""overweight""-rated Eaton Corp and ""equal-weight""-rated Pentair preferred plays
column4: given both companies' leverage to infrastructure investments and attractive relative valuation.

column1: Utilities and clean energy sector: ""Hillary Clinton has been an outspoken advocate of renewable energy and improving resiliency of the electric grid
column2: while Donald Trump has made numerous statements in support of fossil fuels. We see a Trump presidency as largely maintaining the current level of utility infrastructure spend
column3: while a Clinton presidency could result in meaningful upside
column4: particularly in clean energy. Thus
column5: from the standpoint of long-term growth
column6: we see a positive risk/reward for utilities going into the election.""       TONY DWYER

column1: Market moves: ""In this presidential election
column2: there is no social mandate coming from economic dislocation
column3: nor a likelihood of any party receiving a super majority that would cause major legislative change. As a result
column4: any election-based (market) movement - before and after - should prove temporary. Clearly
column5: there is a lot of rhetoric
column6: but that does not equal legislative success.""SEAN DARBY

column1: Global markets: ""We analyzed equity returns before and after the U.S. election. The Hang Seng tends to do well one month before the election and then performs till the end of the year. The Nikkei 225 tends to do well one month afterwards. Interestingly
column2: the VIX consistently rises one and three months before the election while the dollar tends to strengthen. Bonds tend to do better after the election result going into the year-end.""ROB MARTIN
column3: SENIOR U.S. ECONOMIST
column4: BARCLAYS CAPITAL

column11: and 'use every lawful presidential power to remedy trade disputes'.""  CHRIS KRUEGER

WASHINGTON Lockheed Martin Corp unit Lockheed Martin Aeronautics Co is being awarded a $743.17 million modification to a previously awarded initial production contract for F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighters
column2: the Pentagon said on Monday.The modification also establishes maximum prices for one F-35A aircraft and one F-35B aircraft for a non-U.S. Department of Defense participant in the F-35 program
column3: the Pentagon said in a statement.

2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-rigged-idUSKBN12G0SU	Trump charges U.S. election results being rigged 'at many polling places'	"
By Emily Stephenson and Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump dug deeper in his efforts to cast doubt on the legitimacy of the U.S. election
column2: saying on Twitter on Sunday that he believed the results were being ""rigged"" at many polling places. His tweet came hours after his vice presidential running mate
column3: Mike Pence
column4: said Republicans would accept the outcome of the Nov. 8 contest between Trump and his Democratic rival
column5: Hillary Clinton.""The election is absolutely being rigged by the dishonest and distorted media pushing Crooked Hillary - but also at many polling places - SAD
column6: Trump wrote on Twitter
column7: in the latest of a series of comments he has made over the past several days calling into question the fairness of the election.Trump
column8: who is trailing Clinton in opinion polls
column9: did not provide any evidence to back his allegations of impropriety at the voting booth. Early voting and voting by mail have begun in many states.In another tweet later on Sunday
column10: Trump blamed ""animals representing Hillary Clinton"" and Democrats in North Carolina for an overnight attack on a local Republican Party headquarters in that state.Local authorities said the building in Hillsborough
column12: had been struck through a front window with flammable material and an adjacent building wall was spray-painted with a swastika and the words ""Nazi Republicans leave town or else.""""Animals representing Hillary Clinton and Dems in North Carolina just firebombed our office in Orange County because we are winning
column13: Trump tweeted.Clinton denounced the attack as ""horrific and unacceptable"" in her own tweet
column14: adding: ""Very grateful that everyone is safe.

column1: 'COORDINATED EFFORT'
Trump
column2: a New York businessman
column3: who has never held elective office
column4: has often said the electoral process is skewed against him
column5: including during the Republican nominating contests
column6: when he disputed the method for winning delegates to the Republican National Convention.His latest complaint of media bias stems from allegations by women that he groped them or made other unwanted sexual advances
column7: after a 2005 video became public in which Trump was recorded bragging about such behavior. He apologized for the video but has denied each of the accusations.""Election is being rigged by the media
column8: in a coordinated effort with the Clinton campaign
column9: by putting stories that never happened into news!"" Trump tweeted on Sunday
column10: a sentiment he also expressed in posts and during rallies in Maine and New Hampshire on Saturday. The comments raised questions both from  Republicans and Democrats about whether he would accept the outcome should he lose to Clinton.Trump said after the first presidential debate in September that he would ""absolutely"" accept the election outcome. But a few days afterward
column11: he told the New York Times: ""We're going to see what happens.""

column1: He has also urged his supporters to keep an eye on voting locations to prevent a ""stolen"" election
column2: which some critics interpreted as encouraging them to intimidate voters.Pence said on Sunday he and Trump would respect the will of the voters.""We'll respect the outcome of this election
column3: said Pence
column4: the Indiana governor. ""Donald Trump said in the first debate that we'll respect the will of the American people in this election. The peaceful transfer of power is a hallmark of American history.""In a weekend statement quoted by media
column5: a spokeswoman for U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column6: the top U.S. elected Republican
column7: said: ""Our democracy relies on confidence in election results
column8: and the speaker is fully confident the states will carry out this election with integrity.""

column1: 'CONSEQUENCES TO RUSSIA'
On Sunday
column2: Pence for the second time in recent weeks broke from Trump on Russia
column3: this time on that country's possible involvement in email hacks tied to the U.S. election
column4: saying Moscow should face ""severe consequences"" if it has compromised U.S. email security. ""I think there's no question that the evidence continues to point in that direction
column5: Pence said. ""There should be severe consequences to Russia or any sovereign nation that is compromising the privacy or the security of the United States of America
column6: Pence said on ""Fox News Sunday.""Russian President Vladimir Putin said last week his country was not involved in trying to influence the U.S. election.Trump
column7: who has been criticized for appearing too close to Russia after he publicly praised Putin's governing style
column8: has questioned the reports of Moscow's involvement. ""Maybe there is no hacking
column9: he said during last week's second debate with Clinton.Trump also contradicted Pence on Russia during that debate. Pence had said the United States should use military force in Syria if Russia continued air strikes to prop up President Bashar al-Assad
column10: but Trump said he disagreed.The third and final debate between Trump and Clinton will be on Wednesday in Las Vegas. (Reporting by Emily Stephenson and Alana Wise; Editing by Bill Trott and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKBN12E1CK	Trump: Sexual-assault accusers 'want to stop our movement'	"
By Steve Holland and Dan Whitcomb
| CHARLOTTE
column2: N.C./LOS ANGELES

column1: CHARLOTTE
column2: N.C./LOS ANGELES Republican U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump on Friday charged that the women accusing him of sexual misconduct fabricated their stories to damage his campaign after two more women came forward with allegations that he had groped them.The new accusations were made by a contestant on his reality TV show ""The Apprentice
column3: who cited a 2007 incident
column4: and by a woman who described an incident from the early 1990s.With the allegations against Trump dominating the campaign
column5: opinion polls show Trump trailing Democratic rival Hillary Clinton. A Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll taken Oct. 7-13 and released on Friday showed Trump behind Clinton by 7 percentage points among likely voters in the Nov. 8 election.Trump has spent more and more time at his rallies denying allegations of groping since a video from 2005 became public a week ago showing him bragging about groping and making unwanted sexual advances. On Friday
column6: in addition to his denials
column7: he suggested that he never would have found two of the women who have made allegations attractive.Summer Zervos
column8: who competed on the fifth season of ""The Apprentice"" in 2006
column9: appeared at a news conference with celebrity attorney Gloria Allred in Los Angeles
column11: touched her breast and tried to get her to lie down on a bed with him during a meeting about a possible job.""He put me in an embrace and I tried to push him away. I pushed his chest to put space between us and I said
column13: get real.' He repeated my words back to me
column15: ' as he began thrusting his genitals
column16: Zervos said.Zervos said she thought Trump was going to take her to dinner to discuss a job
column17: but the meeting took place in his bungalow at the Beverly Hills Hotel.""I wondered if the sexual behavior was some kind of test and whether or not I had passed"" by rejecting it
column19: but Trump later offered her a job at a golf course for half the salary she had requested.Trump released a statement denying her allegations.""I vaguely remember Ms. Zervos as one of the many contestants on 'The Apprentice' over the years. To be clear
column20: I never met her at a hotel or greeted her inappropriately a decade ago
column21: Trump said. ""That is not who I am as a person
column22: and it is not how I've conducted my life.""At his last event of the day on Friday
column24: Trump suggested that his accusers were fabricating their stories for publicity or to damage his campaign. ""It's not hard to find a small handful of people willing to make false smears
column25: he said. Trump said the women may be motivated for financial reasons or political reasons or ""the simple reason they want to stop our movement.""Earlier Friday
column26: the Washington Post published an interview with a woman who said Trump put his hand up her skirt in a crowded New York nightclub in the early 1990s in an unwanted advance.

column1: He did touch my vagina through my underwear
column2: absolutely
column3: Kristin Anderson said in a video interview on the newspaper's website. ""It wasn't a sexual come-on. I don't know why he did it. It was like just to prove that he could do it
column4: she told the newspaper. Anderson could not be reached for comment.Trump's White House campaign has been scrambling to recover from the release a week ago of the 2005 video. While Trump said the video was just talk and he had never behaved in that way
column5: several women subsequently went public with allegations of sexual misconduct against the New York real estate magnate going back three decades.National opinion polls have shown that women voters have been fleeing Trump in large numbers
column6: putting his campaign in free-fall.CAMPAIGN PROVIDES WITNESS

column1: Late on Friday
column2: the Trump campaign put forward a British man who disputed the account of one of the accusers
column3: Jessica Leeds. Leeds
column4: who is now 74
column5: said Trump groped her on a flight to New York
column6: in or around 1980. Her account was published in The New York Times earlier this week and she has since been interviewed on CNN.

column1: The New York Post reported that the man
column2: Anthony Gilberthorpe
column3: contacted the Trump campaign after Leeds went public with her story
column4: and said he was sitting near Leeds and Trump in first class on the same flight. ""I was there
column5: I was in a position to know that what she said was wrong
column6: wrong
column9: who is now 54 and would have been a teenager at the time.Trump had been promising that he would soon provide information showing the allegations against him were false.Gilberthorpe is known in Britain for his claims that he provided underage boys to British politicians for sex parties in the 1980s.Trump
column12: she would not be my first choice
column15: a reporter who wrote in People magazine that Trump kissed her and pinned her against a wall
column16: a ""liar"" and told the rally to ""check out her Facebook page

column1: TAKE THE HIGH GROUND""
Many Republicans have sought to distance themselves from Trump. The most senior of them
column2: House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column3: angered Trump when he announced this week he would no longer campaign for Trump or defend him but would focus on trying to preserve the Republican majorities in both the House and the Senate in the election.Ryan gave a campaign speech in Madison
column4: Wisconsin
column5: on Friday without mentioning Trump's name once. He urged college students to look beyond the ""ugliness"" of the presidential campaign to focus on issues such as tax and healthcare reform.""The kind of election we really want to have
column6: it's not the one we're necessarily having right now
column8: urging students to ""take the high ground.""Trump on Friday also accused Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim
column9: the top shareholder in The New York Times Company
column10: of helping to generate the reports of sexual misconduct.He said Slim
column11: as a donor to the Clinton Foundation charity and who holds a 17.35 percent stake in the Times
column12: has an interest in helping Clinton's White House campaign.Arturo Elias
column14: said Slim had ""absolutely no contact"" with the newspaper's reporters or editors on their Trump campaign coverage and ""zero"" contact with the paper's news operations.New York Times publisher Arthur Sulzberger Jr. said in a statement
column15: ""Carlos Slim is an excellent shareholder who fully respects boundaries regarding the independence of our journalism. He has never sought to influence what we report.""    Trump's allegation about Slim was the latest chapter in a running series of skirmishes he has had with Mexico and Mexicans.Trump kicked off his campaign last year accusing Mexico of sending rapists and drug dealers to the United States
column16: and promised to build a wall along the southern U.S. border and said he would make Mexico pay for. (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson
column23: Timothy Gardner; Writing by James Oliphant
column25: and Doina Chiacu; Editing by Howard Goller and Leslie Adler)"

NEW YORK Silicon Valley heavyweight Peter Thiel will give $1.25 million as his first donation in support of Donald Trump's campaign after endorsing the U.S. Republican presidential candidate earlier this year
column2: a spokesman for the investor said on Sunday.The donation will be made through a combination of political action committee donations and money directly to the campaign

column1: The New York Times first reported news of Thiel's donation.A co-founder of PayPal and an early investor in Facebook Inc who sits on that company's board of directors

column1: Thiel has not made any donations to the campaign of Trump's opponent in the Nov. 8 election
column2: Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-cyber-idUSKBN12G0XN	U.S. officials step up rhetoric on Russia link to email hacks	"
Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence said on Sunday that evidence implicated Russia in recent email hacks tied to the Nov. 8 U.S. election
column2: contradicting his running mate
column3: Donald Trump
column4: who has cast doubt on Russia's involvement.Pence's comments came after U.S. Vice President Joe Biden said in an interview that aired on Sunday that the United States would be sending a message to Russia ""at the time of our choosing"" about the email attacks. Obama administration officials initially refused to say if they thought Russia was behind the attacks
column5: before accusing Moscow for the first time earlier this month.JULY 26

8	http://reuters.com/article/us-russia-usa-cybercrime-idUSKBN12G0H1	Putin dismisses U.S. hacking allegations as campaign rhetoric	"
By Denis Pinchuk
| GOA
column2: India

column1: GOA
column2: India Russian President Vladimir Putin on Sunday shrugged off new U.S. threats to retaliate against alleged Russian hackers
column3: saying such statements only confirmed that Washington used cyber attacks for political ends.Speaking after a summit of developing economies in India Putin also said he believed that the hacking allegations were mainly election campaign rhetoric by the White House
column4: and that he hoped bilateral ties could improve after the U.S. elections.U.S. Vice President Joe Biden told NBC News television on Friday that ""we are sending a message"" to Putin
column5: and that retaliation for Russia's hacking attacks ""will be at the time of our choosing
column6: and under the circumstances that will have the greatest impact"".The U.S. government this month formally accused Russia for the first time of a campaign of cyber attacks against Democratic Party organizations ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.

column1: You can expect anything from our American friends. But what did he say that was new? Don't we know that official bodies of the United States are spying and eavesdropping on everyone?"" Putin told reporters after the summit of leaders from Brazil
column2: Russia
column3: India
column4: China and South Africa.""The only new thing is that for the first time the United States has recognized at the highest level ... that they themselves do it (cyber attacks).""Putin said that by ""playing the Russian card"" in the current election campaign
column5: the outgoing U.S. administration sought to distract voter attention from its failures
column6: which include huge state debt
column7: weak diplomacy in the Middle East and strained relations with its allies in that region.

column1: I would like to reassure everyone
column2: including our U.S. partners and friends - we do not intend to influence the U.S. election campaign
column3: he said.Putin said he would work with any U.S. leader willing to work with Russia.

column3: he said. ""On the contrary
column4: we would like to find common ground and cooperate in solving the global problems that confront both Russia and the United States."" On Thursday

column6: saying that ""the level of Russophobic propaganda coming from the very top is now starting to go off the scale"". (Reporting by Denis Pinchuk; Writing by Olzhas Auyezov and Dmitry Solovyov; Editing by Kevin Liffey)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-wallstreet-idUSKBN12F0T0	Transcripts of Clinton's Wall Street talks released in new Wikileaks dump	"
By Emily Stephenson and Luciana Lopez

U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's full remarks to several Wall Street audiences appeared to become public on Saturday when the controversial transparency group Wikileaks dumped its latest batch of hacked emails.The documents showed comments by Clinton during question-and-answer sessions with Goldman Sachs Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein and Tim O'Neill
column2: the bank's head of investment management
column3: at three separate events in 2013 in Arizona
column4: New York and South Carolina. Some excerpts of Clinton's speeches had already been released. For more than a week
column5: Wikileaks has published in stages what it says are hacked emails from the account of John Podesta
column6: Clinton's campaign chairman. Clinton's campaign has declined to verify the emails. Goldman Sachs did not immediately provide any comment on Saturday.

column1: Clinton came under fire for months for not releasing full details of her paid speeches to big business audiences
column2: as opponents accused her of a cozy relationship with bankers and other members of the U.S. financial system.The excerpts that have surfaced so far angered voters who backed Clinton's former Democratic opponent
column3: U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders
column4: who endorsed her after losing the party's primary.

column1: Few of these voters are expected to vote for Republican nominee Donald Trump
